channel.title: stdout security
channel.description:
Bite-sized, daily Cyber Security wrap-ups to get you prepped for your day.
Note: This is an AI-generated summary of News Articles from the past 24 hours. I take no credit for the research or analysis in said articles - this podcast only exists as a simple audio summary to help busy, sleep-deprivd Cyber Nerds like myself keep on top of developments while wranging kids and brushing teeth.
channel.author: Opalsec
channel.itunes:author: Opalsec
channel.itunes:summary: Bite-sized, daily Cyber Security wrap-ups to get you prepped for your day.

item.title: Daily News Update: Thursday, October 16, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout: Daily Cyber Briefing üö®

Unpacking a sophisticated nation-state cyberattack on F5's BIG-IP product development environment, which led to source code exfiltration and CISA's emergency directive ED 26-01. Patches have been released for 44 vulnerabilities.

Stay alert to active exploitation of a critical unauthenticated RCE (CVE-2025-2611, CVSS 9.3) in ICTBroadcast autodialer software. We also cover the UK ICO's hefty ¬£14M fine against Capita for its 2023 breach, exposing 6.6 million records, and a new phishing campaign targeting LastPass and Bitwarden users with fake breach alerts to deploy remote access tools.

‚öôÔ∏è Our research segment highlights new threats: malicious VSCode extensions from "TigerJack" stealing source code and executing RCE, plus over 550 leaked secrets found in other extensions. Discover how Chinese state-linked actor "Jewelbug" conducted espionage against a Russian IT provider, and why synced passkeys pose a significant enterprise security risk due to cloud account recovery flaws.

üîí Get the lowdown on critical vulnerabilities: two CVSS 10.0 RCE flaws in Red Lion Sixnet RTUs impacting industrial control systems, SAP's patches including a critical NetWeaver AS Java deserialization RCE (CVE-2025-42944, CVSS 10.0), and Senator Cassidy's call for more details on severe Cisco ASA vulnerabilities that reportedly breached a federal agency.

‚öñÔ∏è Plus, New York state fined eight car insurance companies $14.2M for data breaches affecting over 825,000 individuals, and a 19-year-old was sentenced for the PowerSchool hack exposing 70 million student and teacher records. We also touch on concerns regarding CISA's workforce reductions and the termination of its MS-ISAC agreement.

item.title: Daily News Update: Wednesday, October 15, 2025
item.description:
‚ö°Ô∏è stdout: Your Daily Cyber Briefing ‚ö°Ô∏è

Dive into the last 24 hours of critical infosec developments. We're tracking active cyber events, new attack techniques, and exploited vulnerabilities impacting organisations globally. This episode covers significant breaches at Asahi and Qantas, plus Michigan City's ransomware woes. Don't miss the US/UK's coordinated sanctions and Bitcoin seizure targeting Cambodia's Prince Group, indicted for "pig butchering" scams and human trafficking. üá¶üá∫

üî¨ Our threat research deep dive reveals Chinese state-backed Flax Typhoon's year-long persistence on ArcGIS servers via weaponised SOEs and covert C2. We also unpack malicious packages across npm, PyPI, and RubyGems using Discord webhooks for data exfiltration, alongside North Korean "Contagious Interview" campaigns targeting Web3 developers with over 300 malicious npm packages. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

üö® Get the lowdown on critical vulnerabilities, including Microsoft's October 2025 Patch Tuesday with six zero-days ‚Äì two actively exploited in Windows Agere Modem Driver (CVE-2025-24990) and Remote Access Connection Manager (CVE-2025-59230), both added to CISA's KEV catalog. Oracle issued an emergency patch for an actively exploited pre-auth SSRF in E-Business Suite (CVE-2025-61884), publicly leaked by ShinyHunters. Fortra's GoAnywhere MFT (CVE-2025-10035) is also under active exploitation by Storm-1175 for ransomware campaigns. üí•

We also cover Microsoft Edge's IE mode restrictions due to unpatched Chakra JavaScript engine zero-days, AMD's "RMPocalypse" fix (CVE-2025-0033) for critical EPYC processor flaws, and the Android "Pixnapping" side-channel attack (CVE-2025-48561) stealing sensitive data. Plus, a concerning UEFI shell 'memory modify' command found in 200,000 Linux Framework systems, enabling Secure Boot bypass. üíª

üåç In broader threat landscape news, the UK's NCSC reports a record surge in "nationally significant" cyberattacks, while Taiwan faces a 17% increase in daily Chinese cyber intrusions targeting critical infrastructure, combined with information warfare. Florida's AG is suing Roku over alleged collection and sale of children's sensitive data. ‚öñÔ∏è

Finally, we touch on the evolving threat landscape driven by AI-generated malware, the need for Continuous Threat Exposure Management, Mozilla's new built-in Firefox VPN beta, and a public dispute between FuzzingLabs and Gecko Security over CVE credit attribution. Stay informed, stay secure! üõ°Ô∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Tuesday, October 14, 2025
item.description:
Stay ahead with stdout's daily intel! üöÄ This episode unpacks critical active threats: over 100 SonicWall SSLVPN accounts compromised via stolen credentials. The Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters group has leaked data from 6 million Qantas and 7.3 million Vietnam Airlines customers, alongside Gap and Fujifilm. üè• Medusa ransomware is behind a breach impacting 1.2 million SimonMed Imaging patients, and Clop ransomware exploited an Oracle E-Business Suite zero-day (CVE-2025-61882) in a Harvard University incident.

Discover emerging TTPs and critical vulnerabilities. ü§ñ We analyse ChaosBot, a new Rust-based backdoor leveraging Discord for C2, alongside a destructive Chaos-C++ ransomware variant. The Astaroth banking trojan now employs GitHub steganography for C2 resilience. üö® On the vulnerability front, Microsoft has restricted IE Mode in Edge due to active exploitation of unpatched IE Chakra JavaScript engine zero-days. Oracle released an emergency patch for CVE-2025-61884, an unauthenticated info disclosure flaw in E-Business Suite, following active exploitation of CVE-2025-61882 by Clop.

Beyond the headlines, we examine the expanding RondoDox botnet, weaponising over 50 vulnerabilities with an 'exploit shotgun' approach, and a 100,000+ IP botnet actively targeting RDP services in the US. ‚öñÔ∏è Regulatory updates include Ofcom's first fine under the UK Online Safety Act and an Austrian DPA ruling against Microsoft 365 Education's data tracking. Plus, the Dutch government's intervention in Nexperia and Ukraine's steps towards a dedicated military Cyber Force.

item.title: Daily News Update: Monday, October 13, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout: Your 24-Hour Cyber Brief üö®

Get the essential intel for cyber security analysts. Today, we're dissecting critical vulnerabilities and active threat campaigns from the last 24 hours.

First, a deep dive into Oracle's E-Business Suite. Oracle has issued an urgent alert for CVE-2025-61884 (CVSS 7.5), a high-severity flaw allowing unauthenticated, remote HTTP access to compromise Oracle Configurator. This vulnerability grants attackers unauthorised access to critical data across versions 12.2.3 through 12.2.14. We also revisit the recently exploited zero-day, CVE-2025-61882, leveraged by Cl0p-linked threat actors to deploy malware families including GOLDVEIN.JAVA, SAGEGIFT, SAGELEAF, and SAGEWAVE.

Next, we pivot to a pervasive smishing campaign targeting New Yorkers. Fraudulent text messages impersonating the Department of Taxation and Finance are luring recipients with fake "Inflation Refunds" to steal sensitive personal and financial data for identity theft and fraud. Official warnings confirm New York State's actual refund initiative is automatic, with agencies explicitly stating they will not contact taxpayers via text, phone, or email for these refunds.

Tune in for a concise summary of active cyber events, new techniques, and exploited vulnerabilities.

item.title: Daily News Update: Sunday, October 12, 2025
item.description:
üö® Get the daily rundown on critical cyber security developments! Today, we're dissecting a widespread compromise impacting **SonicWall SSL VPN devices**, where threat actors are rapidly authenticating into over 100 accounts, potentially leveraging valid credentials and exploiting known flaws, including **CVE-2024-40766**, linked to Akira ransomware campaigns. We'll cover crucial mitigation advice for organisations.

üõ†Ô∏è Next, we delve into new threat research revealing threat actors weaponising the open-source DFIR tool **Velociraptor** in ransomware attacks. The group Storm-2603 exploits **SharePoint vulnerabilities** for initial access, deploying an outdated Velociraptor version susceptible to **CVE-2025-6264** for privilege escalation and endpoint takeover. We detail their lateral movement tactics, including GPO modifications and disabling real-time protection.

‚öñÔ∏è We also cover the legal fallout from the **PowerSchool breach**, where a 19-year-old faces a seven-year prison term for accessing 60 million student and 9 million teacher records and demanding a 30 Bitcoin ransom. Plus, significant leadership changes within **US Cyber Command and the NSA**, as President Trump opts not to nominate Army Lt. Gen. William Hartman.

item.title: Daily News Update: Saturday, October 11, 2025
item.description:
üö® **stdout: Daily Cyber Briefing** üö®

Your daily dive into the last 24 hours of cyber security developments! Unpacking critical incidents, we detail the Cl0p ransomware group's exploitation of an Oracle E-Business Suite zero-day (CVE-2025-61882), compromising dozens of organisations for RCE and data exfiltration. Explore the FBI and French authorities' takedown of BreachForums, operated by ShinyHunters and Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters, just before a threatened Salesforce data leak. Plus, we cover the significant data breach at UK trade union Prospect, exposing sensitive member data, and Microsoft's warning about the "payroll pirate" Storm-2657 group targeting US university payroll systems with sophisticated AiTM phishing.

üî¨ **New Threats & Techniques:** Discover ClayRat, a new Android spyware mimicking popular apps and propagating via SMS, capable of extensive data theft and remote control. We also expose the "Beamglea" credential phishing campaign, leveraging 175 malicious npm packages as redirect infrastructure to harvest Microsoft credentials.

üçé **Vulnerabilities & Updates:** Apple has dramatically expanded its bug bounty programme, now offering up to $2 million for zero-click RCEs. Stay informed on Windows 11 23H2 Home and Pro editions reaching end of servicing on November 11, 2025. We also touch on Google Chrome's new feature to automatically revoke notification permissions for inactive websites, the halted trial of officers accused of Baltic Sea cable damage, and the amusing tale of pro-Russian hacktivists TwoNet falling for a Forescout honeypot.

item.title: Daily News Update: Friday, October 10, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout Daily Briefing: Your essential 24-hour cyber security update! üö®

This episode unpacks critical active threats and exploited vulnerabilities. We dive into the widespread SonicWall cloud backup breach, confirming all customers had firewall configuration files accessed via brute-force. Plus, Discord clarifies its third-party incident, revealing 70,000 government IDs exposed through a compromised Zendesk agent. üõ°Ô∏è

Catch up on the relentless Clop ransomware group, actively exploiting a zero-day (CVE-2025-61882) in Oracle E-Business Suite, chaining multiple vulnerabilities for pre-authenticated RCE. Discover how "Payroll Pirates" (Storm-2657) are targeting US universities and other organisations, using phishing to divert salaries via compromised HR platforms. We also explore Russian hackers' increasing use of AI in cyberattacks against Ukraine, from phishing to advanced malware like WRECKSTEEL. üí∏

Further analysis covers the new RondoDox botnet's "exploit shotgun" approach against 56 n-day vulnerabilities, and how China-based Storm-2603 is weaponising the Velociraptor DFIR tool in LockBit and Babuk ransomware attacks. Understand why token theft is a primary cause of SaaS breaches, often bypassing MFA, and the evolving threat from pro-Russian hacktivist group TwoNet, now targeting critical infrastructure with old XSS exploits. Finally, a critical authentication bypass (CVE-2025-5947) in the Service Finder WordPress theme is under active exploitation, granting unauthenticated admin access. üí•

Stay informed on the proposed PACT Act, aiming to extend vital cyber threat information sharing protections. Get the facts, fast. üöÄ

item.title: Daily News Update: Thursday, October 9, 2025
item.description:
üö® Salesforce refused a ransom from "Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters" for data stolen via social engineering and compromised OAuth tokens. Qilin ransomware hit Japanese giant Asahi, while UK police arrested suspects over the Kido nursery doxing. A US law firm reported a China-linked zero-day breach targeting attorney emails for national security intelligence.

üî¨ New threat research highlights OpenAI disrupting Russian, North Korean, and Chinese actors misusing ChatGPT for malware and phishing. Ukraine's CERT-UA details Russian AI-driven attacks and "Steal & Go" tactics, including exploitation of Roundcube's CVE-2023-43770. China-linked actors used Nezha, Ghost RAT, and AntSword in politically motivated espionage across Asia, and the "Crimson Collective" targeted AWS cloud environments for data theft and extortion. A new FileFix variant employs cache smuggling to deliver malicious ZIPs.

üí• Critical vulnerabilities in focus include a severe command injection (CVE-2025-53967) in figma-developer-mcp allowing RCE, now patched. Active exploitation of CVE-2025-5947, a critical authentication bypass in the Service Finder WordPress theme, enabled unauthenticated admin logins with over 13,800 attempts recorded.

üåê Broader developments cover Ursula Von der Leyen's warning on Russia's "hybrid warfare" against Europe, Germany's opposition to the EU's "Chat Control" legislation, and Docker's new unlimited access to Hardened Images for startups and SMBs, offering secure software bundles with near-zero CVEs.

item.title: Daily News Update: Wednesday, October 8, 2025
item.description:
Catch up on the latest cyber incidents impacting global giants and sensitive data. üö® **Jaguar Land Rover** faces a "cyber shockwave" post-attack, while **Doctors Imaging Group** discloses a year-late breach affecting 171,000+ patients. **Discord** users' sensitive info was exposed via a third-party, and **Avnet** confirms a data breach with claims of 1.3TB exfiltrated. The **Red Hat** breach escalates with ShinyHunters joining extortion efforts, leaking customer network details. Plus, **DraftKings** battles credential stuffing attacks.
On the vulnerability front, the notorious **Clop ransomware group** has been actively exploiting a critical zero-day, `CVE-2025-61882`, in **Oracle E-Business Suite** since August 2025. üí• This RCE flaw (CVSS 9.8) allowed unauthenticated attackers to gain control, leading to massive data theft and reported $50M extortion demands. Oracle has patched, and CISA has added it to their Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalogue.
New threat research reveals the evolution of **XWorm malware** to version 6.0, now packed with 35+ plugins for extensive data theft and ransomware capabilities. üêõ Meanwhile, **North Korean hackers (Lazarus Group)** set a new record, stealing over $2 billion in cryptocurrency in 2025, primarily funding nuclear weapons development and shifting tactics from DeFi exploits to social engineering.
The impact of AI on cybersecurity is rapidly expanding. ü§ñ A LayerX report highlights **AI tools as the leading uncontrolled channel for corporate data exfiltration**, with 77% of employees copy-pasting sensitive data into unmanaged GenAI accounts. OpenAI's latest report confirms threat actors are leveraging AI to *enhance existing hacking methods* ‚Äì from malware development to spearphishing ‚Äì rather than creating entirely new ones.
In regulatory news, **Russia implements a mandatory 24-hour mobile internet blackout** for foreign SIM cards upon entry, citing national security. üá∑üá∫ On a brighter note, **Google launches a dedicated AI Vulnerability Reward Program**, offering up to $30,000 for critical flaws in its AI systems. However, Google has controversially stated it will *not* fix **ASCII smuggling attacks in Gemini**, dismissing the LLM manipulation as a social engineering issue.

item.title: Daily News Update: Tuesday, October 7, 2025
item.description:
üö® Critical Exploits & Breaches Unpacked: Dive into the latest active cyber events, including Clop ransomware's exploitation of a new Oracle E-Business Suite zero-day (CVE-2025-61882) for unauthenticated RCE, with public exploit code now available. We also cover Medusa ransomware (Storm-1175) leveraging a Fortra GoAnywhere MFT deserialisation flaw (CVE-2025-10035), and a Zimbra Collaboration zero-day (CVE-2025-27915) used against the Brazilian military. Immediate patching is crucial as agencies worldwide issue urgent warnings. üõ°Ô∏è

üí• Major Incidents & Campaigns: Get the lowdown on the Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters' crowdsourced extortion scheme and their OAuth token abuse impacting Zscaler. We analyse Discord's data breach via a compromised third-party vendor, the significant production halt at Jaguar Land Rover due to a cyberattack, and a suspected China-linked cyber-espionage campaign targeting European institutions. Plus, a leaked report suggests FEMA's CISO and CIO were fired following a June breach. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

üî¨ New Threats & Vulnerabilities: Explore the resurgence of the XWorm backdoor, now featuring a ransomware module and extensive plugins. We detail "RediShell" (CVE-2025-49844), a 13-year-old use-after-free vulnerability in Redis allowing authenticated RCE, and a critical flaw (CVE-2025-59489) in the Unity game engine affecting multiple platforms. Also, a significant surge in scanning attacks targeting Palo Alto Networks GlobalProtect portals has been observed. üíª

üåê Industry & Regulatory Watch: Stay informed on the European Commission's controversial "Chat Control" proposals, with Signal threatening to exit the EU market if passed. LinkedIn is suing ProAPIs Inc. for alleged data scraping, while House Democrats question DHS over an ICE contract with Israeli spyware company Paragon Solutions. We also cover Georgia Tech's $875K settlement for cybersecurity failures, Wiz's $4.5M "Zeroday Cloud" hacking competition, and China's severe crackdown on cybercrime. ‚öñÔ∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Monday, October 6, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout: Your Daily Cyber Security Briefing üö®

Stay ahead of the curve with today's critical cyber developments. We're diving deep into an actively exploited zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-27915, impacting Zimbra Collaboration Suite versions 9.0, 10.0, and 10.1. Discover how malicious iCalendar files üóìÔ∏è delivered sophisticated JavaScript payloads to steal credentials, emails, and sensitive data from a Brazilian military organisation, leveraging the Zimbra SOAP API for exfiltration and mail forwarding. Learn about the TTPs linked to UNC1151 and the urgent patches released on January 27th. ‚úÖ

Then, we'll unpack the resolution of ParkMobile's 2021 data breach class action lawsuit. Understand the $32.8 million settlement, the $1 in-app credit compensation for 22 million affected users, and the extensive data types exposed. Plus, get the latest on ParkMobile's current warnings regarding ongoing SMS phishing (smishing) attacks üì± targeting their customer base. Stay informed, stay secure. üõ°Ô∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Sunday, October 5, 2025
item.description:
stdout: Daily InfoSec Briefing

Stay ahead with stdout! üöÄ Your daily deep dive into the latest in cybersecurity. This episode unpacks a significant Discord data breach affecting PII, government IDs, and partial billing information, stemming from a compromised third-party provider. Understand the financial motivations and the critical implications for identity theft and crypto scams. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Next, we dissect "CometJacking," a novel prompt injection technique targeting Perplexity's agentic AI browser, Comet. Discover how malicious URLs can siphon sensitive data from connected services like email and calendar, bypassing traditional protections through trivial Base64 encoding. Learn why researchers are flagging new AI-native security risks, despite vendor claims of "no security impact." ü§ñ Finally, we examine a nearly 500% surge in scanning activity targeting Palo Alto Networks login portals. GreyNoise reports this mirrors pre-CVE disclosure patterns seen with recent Cisco ASA zero-days, urging organisations to ensure their software is running the latest versions. Don't get caught out! üö®

item.title: Daily News Update: Saturday, October 4, 2025
item.description:
üö® Cyber Alert: stdout Daily Briefing üö®

Tracking significant active threats and breaches impacting global organisations over the last 24 hours.

The notorious ShinyHunters group, also known as "Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters," has launched a data leak site, claiming 1 billion records from 39 companies (including FedEx and Google) via Salesforce breaches, demanding a ransom. Meanwhile, a group linked to Clop ransomware is extorting Oracle E-Business Suite customers, exploiting critical RCE flaws and bypassing SSO/MFA. Red Hat confirms a breach of its consulting GitLab by "Crimson Collective," exposing architectural diagrams and authentication tokens. Japanese giant Asahi Group Holdings suffered a ransomware attack, and Renault/Dacia UK customers were impacted by a third-party data breach. The US Courts also detail ongoing upgrades following a major breach.

Uncover new threat intelligence: Meet "Cavalry Werewolf," a new actor targeting Russian sectors with FoalShell and StallionRAT via phishing. The Rhadamanthys info stealer evolves with advanced fingerprinting and steganography for payload concealment. Researchers expose "CommetJacking," a prompt-injection attack on Perplexity's Comet AI browser that exfiltrates sensitive data. Plus, insights into "PRISONBREAK," an Israeli-backed network using AI deepfakes for propaganda in Iran.

Stay informed on critical vulnerabilities, privacy shifts, and security innovations. Oracle urges patching for E-Business Suite RCEs, while Perplexity downplays its AI browser prompt injection. We also cover privacy concerns around Flock Safety's "Raven" gunshot detection, the UK's proposed digital ID, and the US Courts' response to their major breach. Finally, explore Signal's new SPQR for quantum resistance and Google Workspace's end-to-end encryption rollout for enterprise users.

item.title: Daily News Update: Friday, October 3, 2025
item.description:
üö® **stdout: Your Daily Cyber Intel Briefing** üö®

Dive deep into the last 24 hours of cyber security developments. We unpack major active events, including the alleged Crimson Collective breach of Red Hat's GitHub, impacting customer IT blueprints and authentication tokens. Hear about the suspected ransomware attack disrupting Asahi Group Holdings' operations in Japan, and the social engineering incident that froze Kodex Global's domain. Plus, we cover the high-volume email extortion campaign targeting Oracle E-Business Suite customers by Clop-linked actors, and significant data breaches at Allianz Life Insurance (linked to Scattered Spider) and Motility (Pear ransomware).

üîé On the vulnerability front, get the lowdown on DrayTek's critical RCE flaw (CVE-2025-10547) affecting Vigor routers, allowing unauthenticated remote code execution. ESET reveals two new Android spyware campaigns, ProSpy and ToSpy, actively targeting UAE users via fake messaging apps. We also highlight a massive 540% surge in AI vulnerabilities, particularly prompt injection, reported by HackerOne.

üåç Beyond the exploits, we examine the expanding global reach of North Korean IT worker schemes, now targeting diverse industries. Stay informed on regulatory shifts as a Dutch court rules against Meta's profiled feeds under the EU Digital Services Act, and EU Parliament members question the funding of commercial spyware. Finally, we cover Georgia Tech's $875K settlement for lax cybersecurity on federal research projects and Microsoft's move to discontinue inline SVG images in Outlook for enhanced security.

item.title: Daily News Update: Thursday, October 2, 2025
item.description:
Dive into the last 24 hours of cyber security with stdout! We're tracking significant breaches affecting millions, including WestJet, Allianz Life, and Motility Software Solutions, alongside a potential US Air Force SharePoint incident. Plus, discover how threat actors are exploiting Milesight industrial routers for phishing campaigns across Europe. üö®

Unpack new, sophisticated threats: meet Phantom Taurus, a China-linked espionage group using the stealthy NET-STAR malware, and dissect new Android banking Trojans like Klopatra and Datzbro targeting seniors. We also cover North Korean IT workers expanding their fraudulent job applications and the CABINETRAT backdoor used in targeted attacks in Ukraine. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Get the lowdown on critical vulnerabilities, including a Red Hat OpenShift AI flaw (CVSS 9.9) allowing full cluster admin escalation, and the "WireTap" physical attack bypassing Intel SGX security. Our analysis also highlights the rise of Living Off the Land techniques in high-severity attacks and the ongoing pressure on security professionals to keep breaches confidential. üí•

Finally, we examine data privacy concerns with Tile Bluetooth trackers leaking identifying data and an Adobe Analytics bug exposing customer tracking. Stay informed on regulatory shifts like Google's upcoming Android developer ID verification impacting F-Droid, Imgur's UK exit, and the White House's push for quantum-resistant encryption. Plus, Google Drive rolls out new AI-powered ransomware detection. üõ°Ô∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Wednesday, October 1, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout: Your Daily Cyber Debrief! üö®

Dive into the last 24 hours of cyber security with stdout. We're unpacking critical vulnerabilities under active exploitation, major breaches, and evolving threat tradecraft.

This episode, we analyse critical vulnerabilities under active exploitation: widespread attacks on Cisco ASA/FTD (CVE-2025-20333, CVE-2025-20362) deploying 'Line Viper' and 'RayInitiator' bootkits, and urgent CISA directives for patching critical flaws in Fortra GoAnywhere MFT (CVE-2025-10035) and Sudo (CVE-2025-32463) for privilege escalation. We also cover a VMware zero-day (CVE-2025-41244) actively exploited by Chinese state-sponsored UNC5174, alongside other critical VMware patches and CISA KEV additions. üõ†Ô∏è

In breach news, UK authorities secure a landmark conviction in a ¬£5.5 billion Bitcoin fraud, WestJet confirms a customer data breach, and Asahi reports system disruptions. INTERPOL's "Contender 3.0" operation nets 260 arrests targeting romance scams and sextortion. üí∞

Explore new threat tradecraft with the MatrixPDF toolkit creating interactive phishing lures, and uncover North Korea's expanding illicit IT worker scheme. We also dissect the "Gemini Trifecta" ‚Äì three high-severity vulnerabilities in Google's Gemini AI. ü§ñ

Plus, we cover the EU's Cyber Resilience Act clarifications, CISA's funding cuts to the Center for Internet Security, and the impending expiration of key US cybersecurity legislation. Data privacy takes centre stage with FTC action against the Sendit app, a $1.35M fine for Tractor Supply Co., and the UK's push for nationwide Live Facial Recognition. Finally, Google rolls out AI ransomware detection for Drive, and Afghanistan faces a nationwide internet blackout. üåç

item.title: Daily News Update: Tuesday, September 30, 2025
item.description:
üö® Dive into the last 24 hours of critical cyber developments! üö® We're unpacking major breaches, including Harrods' 430,000 customer records exposed via a third-party supplier, and Jaguar Land Rover's ¬£1.5 billion recovery loan after a production-halting cyberattack. Discover how a federal agency was compromised by an unpatched GeoServer vulnerability, Cloudflare mitigated a record-breaking 22.2 Tbps DDoS attack, and ransomware groups are actively exploiting stolen AWS keys to exfiltrate data. Plus, we cover the impact of a data centre fire in South Korea and cyberattacks marring Moldova's elections.

üõ†Ô∏è Uncover the latest threat intelligence and new techniques: China-linked ArcaneDoor exploited two Cisco firewall zero-days (CVE-2025-20362, CVE-2025-20333) with novel malware, while Iran-linked Nimbus Manticore expanded critical infrastructure targeting using evolving malware and signed code. We detail aggressive Akira ransomware campaigns hitting MFA-protected SonicWall VPNs, the "significantly more dangerous" LockBit 5.0, and the alarming npm supply chain risk from the "postmark-mcp" package silently stealing emails.

‚ö†Ô∏è We also highlight critical vulnerabilities in Supermicro BMCs and the Streamlit framework. Hear about the Medusa ransomware gang's audacious attempt to recruit a BBC journalist as an insider threat, and the broader implications of geopolitical cyber tensions, including alleged Russian espionage. Stay ahead with the essential facts and takeaways from the frontline of information security. üåê

item.title: Daily News Update: Monday, September 29, 2025
item.description:
üö® In this edition of stdout, we dive deep into the latest Akira ransomware activity. Threat actors are actively exploiting SonicWall SSL VPN devices, leveraging an improper access control flaw (CVE-2024-40766) to gain initial access.

üîí Discover how attackers are bypassing one-time password multi-factor authentication (OTP MFA) by utilising previously stolen credentials and OTP seeds, allowing persistent access even after patches. We unpack their post-exploitation tactics, including rapid internal network scanning, Impacket SMB/RDP usage, Active Directory enumeration, and targeting Veeam Backup & Replication servers to extract sensitive MSSQL and PostgreSQL credentials.

‚öôÔ∏è Learn about their sophisticated evasion techniques, specifically Bring-Your-Own-Vulnerable-Driver (BYOVD) attacks. They're abusing Microsoft's consent.exe to sideload malicious DLLs, loading vulnerable drivers to effectively disable endpoint protection.

‚ö†Ô∏è Critical takeaway: Administrators are strongly advised to reset all VPN credentials on any device that previously utilised vulnerable firmware, as stolen accounts can still grant initial access.

item.title: Daily News Update: Sunday, September 28, 2025
item.description:
üö® **Critical Threat Briefing: stdout Daily** üö®

Dive deep into the latest cyber security developments. Today, we're tracking a year-long Chinese state-sponsored espionage campaign, RedNovember (TAG-100/Storm-2077), actively exploiting critical vulnerabilities in internet-facing appliances including Ivanti Connect Secure, Cisco ASA, FortiGate, and Palo Alto GlobalProtect VPNs. Discover their use of the Go-based Pantegana backdoor, Cobalt Strike, and SparkRAT. Plus, CISA and Cisco warn of ongoing ArcaneDoor activity targeting Cisco ASA/FTD firewalls with ROM modifications for persistence. üá®üá≥

Further Chinese-linked threats emerge with a new PlugX variant (Korplug/SOGU) targeting Asian telecommunications and manufacturing, leveraging DLL side-loading. We also cover Mustang Panda's continued use of the advanced Bookworm RAT against ASEAN networks. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

On the malware front, a new malvertising campaign is pushing the Oyster backdoor via fake Microsoft Teams installers. Learn how SEO poisoning, fraudulent certificates, and scheduled tasks are establishing persistence and remote access in corporate networks. üíª

Finally, we examine the concerning trend of minors being recruited for intelligence gathering, following Dutch arrests related to attempts to spy on Europol for Russia. We also touch on Alibaba's ambitious $53 billion global AI infrastructure plan and the geopolitical hurdles it faces, including Nvidia GPU access and data sovereignty concerns for new AI datacentres. üåê

item.title: Daily News Update: Saturday, September 27, 2025
item.description:
🔔 Dive into the latest cyber developments with stdout! üá¶üá∫ This episode unpacks significant breaches, including **Volvo North America's** employee data theft via a ransomware attack on its HR provider, impacting 1.5 million individuals. üö® We also cover **Salesforce** facing lawsuits over customer data exposure from stolen OAuth tokens, and **Union County, Ohio's** ransomware incident compromising sensitive resident data. Plus, hear about two 17-year-olds arrested in the Netherlands for alleged pro-Russian cyber espionage.

💻 Uncover critical new threat research: **Microsoft Threat Intelligence** details an updated, highly obfuscated **macOS XCSSET** variant with enhanced browser targeting and crypto clipboard hijacking. **Trend Micro** warns of **LockBit 5.0**, a "significantly more dangerous" ransomware strain simultaneously targeting Windows, Linux, and VMware ESXi environments. üí• We also break down the "ForcedLeak" attack against **Salesforce's Agentforce AI**, exploiting a DNS misconfiguration for indirect prompt injection and sensitive data exfiltration.

⚠️ Crucially, we delve into actively exploited zero-day vulnerabilities. **Fortra's GoAnywhere MFT** (CVE-2025-10035) saw unauthenticated command injection exploited a week before public disclosure, leading to RCE and backdoor accounts. UK and US agencies have issued urgent directives for **Cisco ASA/FTD** zero-days (CVE-2025-20333, CVE-2025-20362), chained for remote control by the state-sponsored **ArcaneDoor campaign** (UAT4356). Discover the sophisticated **RayInitiator** and **LINE VIPER** malware families deployed for persistence and evasion.

⚖️ Stay informed on regulatory shifts: the **US Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015** faces expiration, and President Trump has approved a plan to restructure **TikTok's US operations** to address national security concerns. Finally, we touch on the **UK ICO's** hefty fines for illegal automated marketing calls, **Interpol's** major cybercrime crackdown in Africa, and **Microsoft Edge's** upcoming feature to revoke malicious sideloaded extensions. üõ°Ô∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Friday, September 26, 2025
item.description:
stdout: Daily Cyber Security Briefing üöÄ

stdout delivers your essential daily update for Cyber Security Analysts, diving deep into the last 24 hours of noteworthy developments, focusing on active threats, new techniques, and critical vulnerabilities.

üö® Active Breaches & Attacks: Kido International suffered a ransomware attack by the Radiant Group, leaking sensitive children's data. The Co-operative Group (UK) reports an ¬£80M profit loss from a Scattered Spider attack that stole 6.5 million member records. A US federal agency was compromised via a GeoServer RCE (CVE-2024-36401), leading to web shells and lateral movement. Plus, an arrest linked to the "incredibly basic" HardBit ransomware affecting European airports.

üõ†Ô∏è Emerging Threats & Techniques: North Korean groups are escalating malware capabilities with AkdoorTea, TsunamiKit, and Tropidoor, targeting crypto developers. Supply chain attacks are rampant: Shai-Hulud worm infected 500+ npm packages, malicious Rust packages stole crypto keys, and an unofficial npm package exfiltrated emails. Learn about AsyncRAT via ScreenConnect, StealC from game patches, Elons ransomware on Oracle DBS, and Android BankBot. Plus, new insights into LNK Stomping and the decade-old BiDi Swap URL spoofing vulnerability.

ü©π Critical Vulnerabilities & Patches: Cisco issues urgent warnings and patches for actively exploited zero-days (CVE-2025-20333, CVE-2025-20362) in ASA/FTD, with a CISA emergency directive. Salesforce patched a critical "ForcedLeak" flaw (CVSS 9.4) in Agentforce AI, allowing CRM data exfiltration. OnePlus OxygenOS has a permission bypass (CVE-2025-10184) for SMS/MMS data, and SonicWall is expediting EOL for SMA 100 devices after rootkit malware discoveries.

üåê Threat Landscape & Geopolitics: Discussions on "AI security" vs. "AI safety" and how AI coding assistants increase security findings. Russian state-backed Storm-1679 targets Moldovan elections with disinformation, and PyPI warns of ongoing phishing attacks. Also, updates on data privacy (Google/Flo, TikTok Canada), the EU's new Entry/Exit System, and law enforcement successes against dark web markets and financial crime.

üí° CTEM Insights: An overview of Continuous Threat Exposure Management, emphasising prioritisation based on business impact and validation through breach and attack simulation.

item.title: Daily News Update: Thursday, September 25, 2025
item.description:
üö® **stdout: Your Daily Cyber Dive!** üö®

This episode unpacks the last 24 hours in infosec, from major arrests to critical exploits. üá¶üá∫

Catch up on the UK arrest linked to the **Collins Aerospace MUSE ransomware attack** impacting European airports, and Boyd Gaming's employee data breach. A 19-year-old has been apprehended as a core figure in the notorious **Scattered Spider** group, linked to 120 attacks and $89.5M in crypto. Interpol's Operation HAECHI VI seized over $439M from cyber-enabled financial crimes. üí∞

New threats include sophisticated **phishing campaigns** targeting Python developers via fake PyPI sites and abusing GitHub notifications to drain crypto wallets. Dive into detailed research on "Brickstorm" (UNC5221), a long-running Chinese cyberespionage campaign targeting legal, SaaS, and tech for IP theft and zero-day development, maintaining persistence for 400 days. Also, discover "RedNovember" (Storm-2077), another Chinese state-sponsored actor exploiting perimeter appliance vulnerabilities from Ivanti, Cisco, and Fortinet. üá®üá≥

Critical vulnerabilities are under active exploitation: a high-severity **Cisco IOS/IOS XE zero-day (CVE-2025-20352)** allowing RCE, and a command injection flaw in **Libraesva Email Security Gateway (CVE-2025-59689)** exploited by state-sponsored actors. We also discuss in-the-wild exploitation of a **Pandoc SSRF (CVE-2025-51591)** targeting AWS IMDS, new **Supermicro BMC firmware vulnerabilities** allowing persistent control, and an unpatched **OnePlus OxygenOS flaw (CVE-2025-10184)** exposing SMS data. üí•

Finally, we examine the broader impact of cyberattacks, including the **Jaguar Land Rover production halt** and the catastrophic collapse of KNP Logistics Group due to an Akira ransomware attack exploiting a single weak password. Plus, a quick look at the new Kali Linux 2025.3 release. Stay informed, stay secure! üõ°Ô∏è

item.title: Daily News Update: Wednesday, September 24, 2025
item.description:
Stay ahead with stdout! üöÄ Your daily deep dive into the last 24 hours of cyber security. Today, we're analysing a record-breaking 22.2 Tbps DDoS attack, a US federal agency breach via unpatched GeoServer RCE (CVE-2024-36401), and major disruptions impacting Jaguar Land Rover, Circle K, and Lotte Card's 3 million customers.

üîç Discover new threats: Iran-backed Nimbus Manticore's novel DLL loading for MiniJunk/MiniBrowse, RevengeHotels leveraging AI-generated VenomRAT, and "Operation Rewrite" using BadIIS for SEO poisoning. Plus, a malicious npm package 'fezbox' employing steganographic QR codes to steal browser cookies.

ü©π Critical vulnerabilities and patches: SolarWinds' third hotfix for a Web Help Desk RCE patch bypass (CVE-2025-26399), SonicWall's update to remove the OVERSTEP rootkit, and an emergency fix for Libraesva's Email Security Gateway (CVE-2025-59689) actively exploited by a suspected state entity. Rapid7 also disclosed an unpatched critical SQL injection in OnePlus OxygenOS (CVE-2025-10184) allowing SMS/MMS data access.

üí° Broader insights include 62% of cyber leaders reporting AI-driven attacks, the link between REST Media and Russia's Rybar disinformation, and GitHub's new mandatory 2FA and granular tokens for npm security. We also touch on the unsustainable model of open source infrastructure and the complexities of North Korean IT worker sanctions compliance.

item.title: Daily News Update: Tuesday, September 23, 2025
item.description:
Daily stdout: Cyber Events, Exploits & Techniques

Your daily deep dive into the latest in cybersecurity! üöÄ Today, we're unpacking significant disruptions, from European aviation chaos caused by a Collins Aerospace ransomware attack to Dallas Fort Worth International Airport's fibre optic woes. Catch up on the latest arrests linked to the 2023 Scattered Spider attacks on MGM and Caesars, costing over $100 million. üí∏ Plus, Stellantis confirms a data leak via a compromised Salesforce provider, with ShinyHunters claiming 18 million records. Even France's Natural History Museum wasn't safe, losing gold nuggets after a ransomware attack disabled security. üèõÔ∏è And a verified Steam game, 'BlockBlasters,' turned malicious, siphoning $150,000 from 261 accounts with a cryptodrainer.

Dive into cutting-edge threat research, including 'EDR-Freeze,' a novel user-mode technique that can indefinitely suspend EDR and antivirus processes without a kernel driver. ü•∂ We also analyse new campaigns: ComicForm targeting Eurasian sectors with Formbook, and the pro-Russian SectorJ149 (UAC-0050) deploying Lumma Stealer, Formbook, and Remcos RAT against South Korean industries. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è LastPass warns macOS users about fake software impersonating password managers, delivering the Atomic (AMOS) info-stealer, now with a backdoor component.

On the vulnerability front, Microsoft patched a critical CVE-2025-55241 in Entra ID (CVSS 10.0), allowing global administrator impersonation. üö® The American Archive of Public Broadcasting also fixed an Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) flaw that exposed private media for years. In the broader threat landscape, AT&T highlights Chinese Salt Typhoon's influence on 'living off the land' techniques, while the FBI warns of spoofed IC3 websites. üåê Lloyds Banking Group's AI implementation shows the tightrope walk between innovation and security, blocking platforms like Hugging Face.

Data privacy takes centre stage with patients advocating for stronger neural data rights as scientists decode inner speech from Brain Computer Interface (BCI) implants. üß† Regulatory hurdles loom as CISA 2015 faces expiration, potentially increasing cyber risk, and Senator Tom Cotton proposes an 18-month 'clean' reauthorization of FISA Section 702 amidst privacy concerns.

Finally, the US government mandates a transition to NIST's new post-quantum cryptography standards by 2030/2035 to counter 'harvest now, decrypt later' threats. üîí ICE HSI has acquired Magnet Forensics' Graykey software for device unlocking. Plus, Mozilla introduces a new Firefox feature allowing add-on developers to roll back to previous approved versions for quicker bug fixes. ü¶ä

item.title: Daily News Update: Monday, September 22, 2025
item.description:
üö® On this episode of stdout, we're diving deep into two critical cybersecurity developments:

  • Microsoft Entra ID Vulnerability (CVE-2025-55241): Discover how a critical flaw, leveraging undocumented "actor tokens" and a deprecated API, could have granted Global Administrator privileges across any Entra ID tenant globally. Learn about the stealthy exploitation potential and Microsoft's swift patch.

üá∞üáµ We then pivot to the evolving tactics of North Korean state-sponsored hacking groups, including Lazarus, ScarCruft (APT37), and Kimsuky (APT43). Expect insights into:

  • Sophisticated Social Engineering: How "ClickFix" lures in fake cryptocurrency job scams deliver malware like BeaverTail and InvisibleFerret, with expanded targeting beyond software developers.
  • ScarCruft's Shift: A notable move from pure espionage to financially motivated and potentially destructive operations, deploying VCD ransomware for the first time, alongside new tools like the Rust-based CHILLYCHINO and FadeStealer. üí∏
  • Kimsuky's Innovation: Abuse of GitHub repositories for malware delivery and data exfiltration, plus their alarming use of OpenAI's ChatGPT to forge deepfake military ID cards in spear-phishing campaigns targeting South Korean defence entities. ü§ñ

item.title: Daily News Update: Sunday, September 21, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout uncovers a critical zero-click vulnerability, codenamed ShadowLeak, in OpenAI ChatGPT's Deep Research agent. Crafted emails leveraging indirect prompt injection could exfiltrate sensitive Gmail inbox data directly from OpenAI's cloud infrastructure, bypassing traditional client-side defences. This flaw, now patched, highlights risks with enabled third-party integrations. üìß

Next, we expose a widespread campaign targeting macOS users with the potent Atomic Stealer malware. Threat actors are deploying fake GitHub repositories impersonating legitimate tools like LastPass and 1Password, using SEO poisoning to push malicious downloads. This campaign underscores persistent social engineering and supply chain compromise tactics. üíª

Finally, a significant regulatory crackdown: the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has shut down the TradeOgre cryptocurrency exchange, seizing over $40 million. This marks Canada's first crypto exchange shutdown, driven by failures in FINTRAC registration and Know Your Customer (KYC) policies, making it a conduit for cybercrime money laundering. üí∞

item.title: Daily News Update: Saturday, September 20, 2025
item.description:
üö® stdout: Your Daily Cyber Briefing üö®

Dive deep into the last 24 hours of cybersecurity with "stdout"! We're breaking down 12 critical topics for technical analysts, focusing on active cyber events, exploited vulnerabilities, and emerging threat techniques. üá¶üá∫

This episode, we cover the arrests of two Scattered Spider affiliates in the UK, linked to over $115 million in ransoms and a US federal court breach. We also track a cyberattack on Russia's Pulkovo Airport and an Iran-nexus group, UNC1549, infiltrating 11 European telecommunications companies via LinkedIn lures and the MINIBIKE backdoor. ‚úàÔ∏è

On the vulnerability front, Fortra warns of a max-severity deserialisation flaw (CVE-2025-10035) in GoAnywhere MFT, mirroring a past Clop zero-day. CISA details malware exploiting Ivanti EPMM zero-days (CVE-2025-4427, CVE-2025-4428), potentially by China-nexus groups. Plus, discover a critical, now-mitigated Microsoft Entra ID flaw (CVE-2025-55241) that could have granted global admin access, and OpenAI's patch for ChatGPT's "ShadowLeak", allowing Gmail secret exfiltration. üí•

New threat research reveals collaboration between Russian state-sponsored groups Gamaredon and Turla, with Gamaredon providing initial access for Turla's Kazuar backdoor. Uncover China's "AI persona army" for information warfare and the surge in Phishing-as-a-Service (PhaaS) platforms like Lighthouse and Lucid, driving 17,500+ phishing domains. We also explore how researchers tricked ChatGPT into solving CAPTCHAs, raising questions about their long-term effectiveness. ü§ñ

Beyond the exploits, MI6 launches a dark web portal "Silent Courier" for informant recruitment, the FBI warns of fake IC3 portals, and the future of the CVE Program is debated amidst funding concerns. Stay ahead with stdout! üí°

item.title: Daily News Update: Friday, September 19, 2025
item.description:
Dive into the latest cyber threats and vulnerabilities impacting the digital landscape. This episode unpacks a massive alleged data theft by **ShinyHunters**, claiming 1.5 billion Salesforce records via a Salesloft supply chain attack, impacting major organisations like Google and Palo Alto Networks. We also cover a confirmed ransomware attack on venture capital firm **Insight Partners** affecting over 12,000 individuals, and a critical breach of **SonicWall's cloud backup service** exposing firewall configurations for a segment of its user base. The healthcare sector remains a prime target, with three separate breaches exposing data for over 850,000 Americans. üè•

Stay informed on active threat actors and emerging techniques: two alleged **Scattered Spider** members have been charged in connection with the Transport for London attack. Discover how the Russian troll farm **CopyCop (Storm-1516)** is leveraging self-hosted LLMs to generate fake news across 200+ sites, and learn about malicious `sisaws` and `secmeasure` packages in PyPI delivering the **SilentSync RAT**. China-backed **TA415 (APT41)** is actively targeting US government and academic organisations with sophisticated phishing, while the **SystemBC botnet** compromises 1,500 commercial VPS daily for malicious traffic. üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Critical vulnerabilities and essential patches: Google has issued an urgent update for a **sixth Chrome zero-day (CVE-2025-10585)** actively exploited in the wild. WatchGuard released security updates for a critical **Firebox RCE (CVE-2025-9242)**, and OpenAI patched a "ShadowLeak" zero-click vulnerability in **ChatGPT's Deep Research agent**. Plus, all PyPI tokens stolen in the recent **GhostAction supply chain attack** have been invalidated. üîí

Finally, we touch on Cloudflare's self-inflicted outage, Brazil's new **Digital ECA law** for child data protection, the confirmation of Katherine Sutton as the Pentagon's new Assistant Secretary of Defence for Cyber Policy, and how federal agencies are increasingly incorporating AI into cyber defences. üåê

item.title: Daily News Update: Thursday, September 18, 2025
item.description: stdout delivers your daily intel. Today, we unpack the ongoing fallout from the Colt Technology Services and Jaguar Land Rover ransomware attacks, a brute-force breach impacting SonicWall's MySonicWall.com, and a sophisticated ransomware incident at Insight Partners. New threat research highlights Microsoft and Cloudflare's takedown of the RaccoonO365 Phishing-as-a-Service, the resurgence of Scattered Spider targeting the financial sector via social engineering and Azure AD SSPR, and how groups like Kimsuky and RevengeHotels are leveraging AI for deepfakes and refined malware. We also delve into 'Phoenix', a new Rowhammer attack (CVE-2025-6202) affecting DDR5 memory, and the resentencing of BreachForums founder 'Pompompurin'.

item.title: Daily News Update: Tuesday, September 16, 2025
item.description: stdout unpacks the last 24 hours in cyber security. We dive into the FBI's FLASH alert on UNC6040/UNC6395 (ShinyHunters/Scattered Spider) compromising Salesforce via vishing and OAuth token exploits, alongside ongoing disruption at Jaguar Land Rover and a ransomware attack forcing a Texas school district closure. Discover how Akira ransomware bypassed MFA in a SonicWall VPN breach using plaintext recovery codes, and the largest npm supply chain compromise to date, impacting billions of downloads after a maintainer was phished. We also cover new SEO poisoning campaigns distributing novel malware, Mustang Panda's updated TONESHELL and geofenced SnakeDisk worm, and Kimsuky spies leveraging ChatGPT for fake IDs. Plus, a new Rowhammer attack variant, "Phoenix," bypasses DDR5 defences to achieve root privileges, and Microsoft warns about SMBv1 connection issues. Stay informed on these critical developments.

item.title: Daily News Update: Wednesday, September 17, 2025
item.description: stdout unpacks the latest in cyber security: Jaguar Land Rover's operations remain suspended following a 'Scattered Lapsus$ Hunters' attack, with the group also creating a fraudulent account in Google's LERS portal. We detail 'Shai-Hulud,' a self-propagating npm worm actively stealing credentials, and the 'FileFix' social engineering technique delivering the StealC infostealer via fake Facebook alerts and steganography. Explore the massive 'SlopAds' ad fraud operation exploiting Android apps, plus the new 'Phoenix' RowHammer variant bypassing DDR5 memory protections. Apple has backported patches for an actively exploited Image I/O zero-day. Also, China's stricter incident reporting mandates, Microsoft's removal of WMIC, and Check Point's acquisition of AI security platform Lakera.
